reasoning: The critique targets a specific argumentative move in the post: rejecting (or heavily discounting) low-substitutability ρ estimates partly because they imply an “implausibly low” max speed, where that implausibility is defended by expert intuition and informal extrapolation. Undercutting this move matters because it supports the author’s preferred range for ρ (e.g., −0.2 to 0), but it is only one of several independent counterarguments the post offers (measurement issues, long-run vs short-run substitution, extrapolation outside observed range, algorithmic efficiency increasing experiments, alternative routes, etc.), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique has moderate strength: it plausibly identifies a circularity/bootstrapping risk (intuition formed in compute-scarce regimes being used to argue compute won’t bottleneck), but it doesn’t show the author’s max-speed judgments are actually wrong—only that they lack an independent anchor—and the position could still stand on the other reasons even if this one is weakened. Most of the critique is correct and conceptually coherent, with high clarity and little dead weight, and it focuses on a single issue.
title: Rejecting economic estimates based on intuitions formed under current conditions is circular
